title: February 11
description:
When we picked up Milo from school last week, he was grinning from ear to ear: "Maman, j'ai une super bonne nouvelle!" (Mom, I have some really great news). He let Lucie give a few guesses before announcing the blessed event : "Jeudi prochain, c'est la grève!!!" (next Thursday, there is a strike). Our kids are loving French politics.

This time, it was just for one day and just for school teachers. They are protesting against all the jobs that are being cut in education.

In other school-related news, Lucie chaperoned a field trip to the Château de Vincennes. She was very excited at the opportunity to meet Felix's classmates and, of course, brought the camera.

children.title: Field Trip
children.description:
Lucie chaperoned the CE2 (third grade) class on a field trip to the Château de Vincennes.

Felix and classmates Benjamin, Alexandre and Nashir wait for the bus.

children.title: Vincennes
children.description: Good old Charles V resided here in the 1300's. By the 1600's it had fallen out of favor and had been turned into a posh jail for political prisoners. The Marquis de Sade was imprisoned here before being moved to the Bastille.

children.title: Christelle
children.description: Christelle, Felix's teacher, surveys her flock.

children.title: Paula
children.description: Paula and Raphaël, both good friends of Felix's.

children.title: Arches
children.description: We dutifully admired all the vaulted arches. It's a nice castle in the early medieval style.

children.title: Fireplace
children.description: The kids loved piling into the immense fireplaces.

children.title: Raphaël
children.description:
Raphaël is the second oldest kid in the class after Felix. They're definitely taller than the rest. They sit next to each other in class and often work together.

Felix claims the teacher has changed everyone's seating arrangements many times during the year except for him and Raphaël. I guess they make a good team.

children.title: Picnic
children.description:
After the castle we headed next door to the Parc Floral.

Cultural difference: in America, kids are discouraged from sharing their lunches at school. In France, school picnics are a much more convivial affair. Almost everyone brought chips, cookies or other food to share with the group.

Also, kids gasped in horror when Lucie suggested tossing away a half-eaten portion of grated carrots (in a non re-closable container) that one child didn't finish. They all agreed that wasting food was a HUGE no-no and that an alternative MUST be found... either finding someone hungry for carrots or some sort of container for the carrot to be eaten later.

children.title: Swing
children.description: Felix rocks the swing with his patented back-and-forth stomping action. Other kids gave it a try but none of them could quite get it right. Felix enjoys being bigger and stronger than his classmates.

children.title: Béthany
children.description: Béthany jumps to the rhythm of "Felix l'Américain" as some kids call him.

children.title: Tires
children.description: Felix is looking a little TIREd, isn't he?

children.title: Basile
children.description: Salut Basile!

children.title: Sketching Group
children.description: Back to the château for a little sketching session.

children.title: Sketching
children.description: Carefully sketching the castle's "machicoulis" (machicolations) and the "meurtrières" (archer slits).

children.title: Dunjon
children.description: The imposing dungeon tower of Château de Vincennes.

children.title: Frédéric
children.description:
Lunch with Frédéric, an old friend from Estienne (a.k.a. École Supérieure des Arts et Industries Graphiques Estienne) where Lucie studied communication design from 1991 to 1994 in Paris.

Lucie is taking avantage of this year to get back in touch with former Estienne classmates. It's been nice to see where the years took them and to gossip about old acquaintances. Frédéric is an illustrator and the creative director at Bayard Presse, an editor that makes popular children magazines such as "J'aime Lire". Tony is a freelance print graphic designer. Peggy is a children's book illustrator. It's good to see that most of us are working in the field we studied for.

children.title: Belleville
children.description:
Felix has been hooked on graffiti since street artists painted their school yard. He can rattle off the "visual signatures" of ten or so artists.

While the teachers were on strike, Dean took the kids to Belleville on a quest to see graffiti done by some of the artists Felix studied.

children.title: There!
children.description: There! No doubt about it, we have spotted one by l'Atlas.

children.title: L'Atlas
children.description: See the maze-like letters in black and white? That's by l'Atlas.

children.title: Tags
children.description:
From his classroom studies, Felix informs us that "tags" are a degenerate sub-form of graffiti that consists mainly of marking your territory with your stylised signature, very much like a dog pissing on a fire hydrant.

It's not as interesting as big murals, but Felix is still wanting to develop his own personal tag.

children.title: Maze
children.description: If you look closely, you'll notice that the maze actually spells Atlas' name.
